com.biorecorder.edflib

Class DataRecordsWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.biorecorder.edflib.DataRecordsWriter
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DataRecordsFilter, EdfWriter

    public abstract class DataRecordsWriter
extends java.lang.Object
    This abstract class is the superclass of all classes representing an output stream of DataRecords. An output stream accepts a digital DataRecord and send (write) it to some sink.

    To write DataRecords to the stream we must open this stream first and pass a HeaderConfig object with the configuration information. That is, call the method open(HeaderConfig). Only after that DataRecords and samples could be written correctly.

    We may write digital or physical DataRecords and samples. Every physical (floating point) value will be converted to the corresponding digital (int) value using physical maximum, physical minimum, digital maximum and digital minimum of the signal.

    Every subclass of DataRecordsWriter must implement the method that writes one digital DataRecord - writeDigitalDataRecord(int[], int)

    See Also:
    EdfWriter, DataRecordsFilter

      • DataRecordsWriter

        public DataRecordsWriter()

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open(HeaderConfig headerConfig)
          throws java.io.IOException
        Prepare the DataRecords writer for correct work. This function MUST be called before writing any data. After opening the configuration of the writer SHOULD NOT be changed.
        Parameters:
        headerConfig - - object with the information about DataRecords structure
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeDigitalSamples

        public void writeDigitalSamples(int[] digitalSamples)
                         throws java.io.IOException
        Write the given digital samples to the inner DataRecord. The input array should contain n samples belonging to one signal where n = (samplefrequency of that signal) * (duration of DataRecord).

        Call this function for every signal (channel) in the file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals in the file, the order of calling this function must be:
        signal 0, signal 1, signal 2, signal 3,
        signal 0, signal 1, signal 2, signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Every time when the inner digital DataRecord is completely formed the method writeDigitalDataRecord(int[]) is called.

        Parameters:
        digitalSamples - digital samples belonging to one signal obtained during the time = duration of DataRecord (usually 1 sec)
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writePhysicalSamples

        public void writePhysicalSamples(double[] physicalSamples)
                          throws java.io.IOException
        Convert the given physical samples to digital and call the method writeDigitalSamples(int[]).

        The input array should contain n samples belonging to one signal where n = (samplefrequency of that signal) * (duration of DataRecord).

        Call this function for every signal (channel) in the file. The order is important! When there are 4 signals in the file, the order of calling this function must be:
        signal 0, signal 1, signal 2, signal 3,
        signal 0, signal 1, signal 2, signal 3,
        ... etc.

        Every time when the inner digital DataRecord is completely formed the method writeDigitalDataRecord(int[]) is called.

        Parameters:
        physicalSamples - array with physical samples to write
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeDigitalDataRecord

        public abstract void writeDigitalDataRecord(int[] digitalData,
                                            int offset)
                                     throws java.io.IOException
        Write ONE digital DataRecord. Take data from digitalData array starting at offset position.
        Parameters:
        digitalData - array with digital data
        offset - offset within the array at which the DataRecord starts
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writePhysicalDataRecord

        public void writePhysicalDataRecord(double[] physData,
                                    int offset)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Convert ONE physical DataRecord to digital one and write it. That is, it performs writeDigitalDataRecord(physicalDigitalConverter.physicalRecordToDigital(physData, offset)). Take data from physData array starting at offset position.
        Parameters:
        physData - array with physical data
        offset - offset within the array at which the DataRecord starts
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeDigitalDataRecord

        public void writeDigitalDataRecord(int[] digitalDataRecord)
                            throws java.io.IOException
        Write the given digital DataRecord. This method do exactly the same as the call writeDigitalDataRecord(dataRecord, 0) method.
        Parameters:
        digitalDataRecord - digital DataRecord to be written to the stream
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writePhysicalDataRecord

        public void writePhysicalDataRecord(double[] physDataRecord)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        Convert the given physical DataRecord to digital one and write it. This method do exactly the same as the call writePhysicalDataRecord(physDataRecord, 0) method.
        Parameters:
        physDataRecord - physical DataRecord to be converted to digital one and written to the stream
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • close

        public abstract void close()
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Closes this writer and releases any system resources associated with it. This writer may no longer be used for writing DataRecords. This method MUST be called after finishing writing DataRecords. Failing to do so will cause unnessesary memory usage and corrupted and incomplete data writing.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
